Column: 333

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

NOISE POLLUTION
(Legislation)


    1. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Prime Minister whether the Government will consider introducing legislation to provide for anti-noise measures.

Column: 334



     The Minister for the Environment (Mr Lim Kim San) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by the Prime Minister to reply to this question.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, at present there are existing regulations enabling several Ministries and departments to act on certain aspects of noise pollution. For instance, the Registrar of Vehicles can take action against

Column: 335

the owner of a vehicle which emits excessive noise. The Ministry of Culture limits the noise coming from outdoor performances and from loudspeakers in record shops, and the Ministry of the Environment can require the occupier of a trade and industrial premises which creates excessive noise to abate the noise. Administratively, the Government pursues a policy against noise pollution. Members are probably aware that Radio and Television Singapore, for instance, regularly makes announcements together with slides encouraging the people to tune down the volume of their TV and hi-fi sets. The police also often acts against persons making excessive noise at unreasonable hours.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no quick and easy answer to the problem of noise pollution in Singapore. Community noise is a particularly difficult problem due to our high population density and the cultural background of our people. However, it can be minimised by inculcating in our citizens a greater sense of civic consciousness and consideration for others. At the present moment, there are no plans to introduce further legislation to provide for anti-noise measures.

Column: 335

PSA ENTRY PASSES FOR STEVEDORES
(Extension of age limit)


    2. Mr Tan Cheng San asked the Prime Minister whether he will consider extending the age limit of stevedores to 65 years for the issue of Port of Singapore Authority passes.

     Mr Lim Kim San (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, all stevedores, employed either by the PSA or private firms, require a pass from the PSA to work at the wharves.

    The work of a stevedore requires heavy physical exertion and quick reflexes. Those who are over 60 years of age are generally slow in their physical responses. This could endanger their own safety and the safety of those who are working with them.

Column: 336



    For this reason, the PSA does not propose to extend the age limit of stevedores beyond 60 years, regardless of whether they are employed by the PSA or the private companies.

Column: 336

SUBSIDY FOR COMMUNITY CENTRES


    3. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Prime Minister whether the Government will increase the subsidy for the building of new community centres in view of inflation.

     The Senior Minister of State, Prime Minister's Office (Mr Lee Khoon Choy) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, Government revised its subsidies for the building of new community centres in October 1977. The total revised subsidy of up to $550,000 was more than 3 1/2 times the previous subsidy of $150,000.

    Nevertheless, because of rising building costs, the People's Association has urged a further revision. A decision will soon be made by the Finance Ministry.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question. If a request for subsidy is not approved, will the Government consider giving a loan to the Building Fund Committee to be repaid in instalments? If a loan can be granted, it will not only help to combat inflation but it will also help certain constituencies to build community centres which are most urgently needed.

     Mr Lee Khoon Choy: Mr Speaker, Sir, if I were a Backbencher I would not pre-empt the decision of the Ministry of Finance. In any case, the suggestion put forward by the Member will be considered.

Column: 336

AIR POLLUTION IN INDUSTRIAL ESTATES
(Measures to reduce)


    4. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Prime Minister whether the air pollution in industrial estates, such as the Jurong Town, and urban areas has reached the state of affecting the health of the residents of those

Column: 337

areas and what steps have been or will be taken to reduce air pollution generally.

     Mr Lim Kim San (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, air pollution is being monitored daily by the Anti- Pollution Unit, and we find that the air pollution in industrial estates and the urban areas is normally higher than in the residential or rural areas. However, the pollution level is well within the level set by the World Health Organisation and at present it does not pose a danger to our health.

    The main sources of air pollution are emissions from industrial premises and motor vehicles and there are existing measures to check air pollution. The Anti-Pollution Unit conducts regular tests on the emissions from factories to check for compliance with existing regulations. Some factories are required to instal anti-pollution equipment. The Registry of Vehicles periodically inspects goods and public service vehicles to ensure that their engines do not emit pollutants excessively.

Column: 337

NON-CITIZEN STEVEDORES WITHOUT WORK PERMITS
(Action against)


    5. Mr Tan Cheng San asked the Minister for Labour whether he is aware that some stevedores working at the wharves do not hold work permits, and what action will be taken against them.

     The Minister of State for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, until now there has been no report of non-citizen stevedores working here without work permits. The Ministry will take enforcement action against those non-citizens who are working here without a work permit.

Column: 337

INCINERATOR AT TOH TUCK ROAD
(Particulars)


    6. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for the Environment (a) how long the incinerator at Toh Tuck Road has been in

Column: 338

operation; (b) how much refuse it is burning per day; (c) how much electricity it is generating; (d) whether there is any excess of electricity generated and how it is utilised; (e) how much refuse is still being dumped at the Tampines disposal ground; and (f) whether and when the Tampines disposal ground will be closed.

     Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, the incinerator at Toh Tuck Road has been functioning since January this year at full capacity, that is, operating three furnaces, and it will be able to burn 1,200 tons of domestic refuse per day. It generates an average of 8.2 megawatts of electricity daily. It uses about 2 megawatts and the surplus of 6.2 megawatts is sold to the Public Utilities Board.

    The quantity of refuse disposed at the Tampines disposal ground has been reduced from an average of 1,300 tons per day to 680 tons per day. The dumping ground will continue to be used because we collect daily an average of 2,400 tons of refuse. Out of the 2,400 tons of refuse, 1,200 tons are burnt. About 680 tons of refuse are now being disposed of at the Tampines ground and the rest at another dumping ground. The refuse will also have to be disposed when the incinerator is shut down for repair or maintenance.

    I regret to inform the hon. Member that the Tampines disposal ground will therefore not be closed at all.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, in view of the fact that the present incinerator at Toh Tuck Road is able to produce 8.2 megawatts of electricity, with an excess of 6.2 megawatts which is sold to the PUB, will the Hon. Minister consider building one or two more incinerators so that the question of having to dispose of refuse at an uneconomic cost at the Tampines dumping ground can be resolved?

     Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, the most economic way of disposing refuse is to dump it at the dumping ground. But that is not our only consideration when we talk about the disposal of refuse. The question is

Column: 339

whether dumping will inconvenience members of the public. We think that further large scale dumping of refuse at Tampines is undesirable. The Government has therefore spent about $90 million to build the incinerator. It is likely that its capacity will be expanded to save the residents of Tampines from further pollution.

Column: 339

JALAN EUNOS
(Flood control measures)


    7. Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi asked the Minister for the Environment (a) whether his Ministry had anticipated the recent floodings at Jalan Eunos in the vicinity of the Pan-Island Expressway flyover, and, if so, why the flood control measures were not effective; (b) what steps are being taken to remedy the flooding problem; how effective those measures will be; and, if they are not effective, whether he will recommend that the families affected by the floodings be resettled immediately; and (c) whether draining flood water into the Siglap Canal will cause overloading of the Canal thereby aggravating the floodings in Pachitan, Changi Road and Frankel Estate; and, if so, whether his Ministry will revise its plans by diverting flood waters elsewhere or into new drainage networks instead of into the Siglap Canal.

     Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, the piece of land between Jalan Eunos and the Pan-Island Expressway flyover now under construction is a part of the low-lying area of Geylang Serai, and it is always prone to floods. There are 20 squatter huts there. The residents there do know that this area is very prone to floods and so out of the 20 huts, 10 are on stilts. The Ministry does not run a weather bureau, but it does know that this area is prone to floods. Part of this low-lying area has been filled up to build the Pan-Island Expressway and, as a result, the rest of the area has become more prone to floods.

    Lately we have been experiencing unusually wet weather and this has led to frequent floods in this area. The Ministry is aware of the plight of the residents there and

Column: 340

has taken remedial measures. Unfortunately, they have not been very effective. Since this is a very low-lying area, flooding cannot be alleviated unless the whole area is filled up. It is not possible to offer resettlement terms to the residents there because the land is privately owned. It does not belong to the Government.

    With regard to the other part of the question, that is, draining the storm water along Jalan Eunos into the Siglap Canal, there is no plan to drain the water from other catchment areas into the Siglap Canal. Therefore, it will not be overloaded and it is unlikely to flood the surrounding area.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan): Supplementary questions, Sir. Was the Drainage Department notified in advance about the construction of the Pan-Island Expressway flyover? If so, did the Drainage Department indicate specifically what drainage measures should be taken to ensure that flooding would be minimised?

    The second question is: why is it that the area now suffers from flooding? For example, the area was flooded on the 27th April and 3rd May, 1979, when the rainfall recorded was only 40 mm and 43.6 mm respectively. Yet in January 1978 when the maximum rainfall for that month was 86 mm the area was not flooded. In making this comparison we have to bear in mind that the construction of the Pan-Island Expressway flyover commenced in March 1978 and the major earthworks were somewhat completed in September/October 1978.

     Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been trying hard to follow closely what the Member said. I am no surveyor. However, I think that the collapse of the flyover has made it more difficult for the water to drain away from this low lying area. As a result, even a slight rainfall would have flooded the area. It is only after the completion of the fly-over and the road that permanent measures to relieve the area of flooding can be considered and undertaken.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi: Sir, I do not wish to appear persistent on this issue. But I

Column: 341

have received petitions, more than four times over, from the constituents there. The question is: was there prior consultation between the Drainage Department and the PWD, so that the Drainage Department could instruct the PWD of the drainage control measures that should be provided before the earth-works started? I raise this question because I understand that this is part and parcel of the code of practice in the Drainage Department before they approve major projects and give clearance before a project can commence.

     Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, normally there is consultation between the departments concerned to try and alleviate any inconvenience that may occur. In this instance, it is not desirable nor possible to undertake all the drainage measures that are required to alleviate this area from flooding before completion of the flyover and the adjacent section of the Pan-Island Expressway. What was done was only a temporary measure. Unfortunately, we have been having unusually wet weather resulting in more flooding than usual.

Column: 341

SAVE ELECTRICITY CAMPAIGN
(Response)


    8. Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng asked the Minister for the Environment (a) who are the largest single group of energy users in Singapore; (b) is this group responding well to the "Save Electricity Campaign" recently launched by the Public Utilities Board, and (c) are there any other deterrent measures that the Board intends to adopt to discourage this group from further wastage of electricity.

     Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, electricity consumers can be grouped under three headings. They are industrial, domestic, commercial and other users. The industrial users form the largest group. They use 50% of the electricity generated, followed by commercial and other users, 33%, and domestic users, 17%. It is too early, however, to tell whether there has been a significant drop in the consumption of electricity by the industries, as the "Save Electricity Campaign" was launched only in April and it will be some

Column: 342

time before we can compile the necessary statistics to make a comparative study.

    The Public Utilities Board is not considering any deterrent measures yet. The emphasis now is to advise the consumers on how to conserve energy and to seek their co-operation. There has been some good response. Some factories are responding. They are studying energy conservation measures. However, these measures again will require modifications to the factory infrastructure. Time, therefore, is required for such modifications, and savings in power can only be seen after the modifications have been effected.

    Again, Mr Speaker, Sir, electricity consumption can be classified according to usage. Air-conditioning uses 26% of the electricity generated; lighting 11% and others 63%. It is possible to economise electricity consumption for air-conditioning without affecting production and efficiency. The PUB is working together with the Ministries of Finance and National Development to encourage owners to improve the insulation of their buildings. This would reduce the heat load on air-conditioners.

Column: 342

DRUG ABUSE
(Particulars)


    9. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether the drug position has improved or deteriorated, and if he is able to give the House breakdown figures of persons convicted in court for drug taking as well as of persons convicted for drug trafficking for the years 1977, 1978 and 1979.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I informed the House at the last Parliamentary sitting on 20th March, 1979, that the spread of heroin abuse in Singapore had been contained. Since then the situation has improved further.

    The Member for Khe Bong has asked for figures of persons convicted in court for drug offences. To give a complete picture, it is necessary to include figures of drug addicts sent to Drug Rehabilitation Centres as well

Column: 343

as drug traffickers and pushers who are detained under the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Act. The figures for drug addicts are as follows: 
                        No.of          No.of
Year                 persons sent     persons      Total
                       to DRCs       convicted

1977                    7,084          1,539       8,623

1978                    5,776          1,704       7,480

1979                      774            428       1,202
(1st quarter)


    The figures for drug traffickers and pushers are as follows: 
                          No.            No.
Year                   detained      convicted     Total

1977                      106            234         340

1978                      178             89         267

1979                       27              6          33
(1st quarter)


     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, the penalty for drug trafficking is different from that for drug taking. Can the Minister inform this House which penalty has achieved the greater effect of reducing the drug crime rate?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, first of all, drug trafficking and drug addiction are two different offences. Drug trafficking is a criminal offence in the sense that a person is trying to sell drugs to drug addicts; in other words, to make money out of human misery. Drug addiction is another matter. Although it is a crime, it is, of course, of a much lesser degree. In fact, as far as drug addiction is concerned, instead of prosecuting the drug addicts in court, we prefer to send them to drug rehabilitation centres for treatment and rehabilitation. In other words, they would not be convicted of a criminal offence, particularly the first offenders. In fact, from the figures I have mentioned, the vast majority of the drug addicts have been sent to drug rehabilitation centres for treatment and rehabilitation instead of prosecuting them in court for sentence and imprisonment. The

Column: 344

drug addicts who were prosecuted were mainly foreigners.

    Sir, I hope I have answered the Member's question.

Column: 344

TOOTING BY SCHOOL BUS
DRIVERS
(Measures to prohibit)


    10. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether his Ministry has any plans to prohibit the sounding of horns by school bus drivers when picking up students in the early morning hours, especially in housing estates, so that noise pollution level can be reduced to enable residents to have a peaceful and quiet morning.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, motorists should only sound the horns of their vehicles to prevent an accident. Sounding of horns unnecessarily is an offence under the Minor Offences Act and the offenders may be liable to a fine of up to 950. Such an offence may also be dealt with under the Motor Vehicles (Construction and Use) Rules and the Road Traffic Act where a fine of up to $1,000 or an imprisonment of up to three months can be imposed.

    The Traffic Police and the Registry of Vehicles will ask the School Bus Owners' Association to cooperate by reminding school bus drivers not to misuse the horn as this will cause noise nuisance, particularly in the early morning hours in housing estates. Action will be taken against those who persist in this inconsiderate act. To educate the motoring public on the proper use of horns, the Traffic Police will highlight this subject in one of their future road safety columns in the press.

Column: 344

HAWKERS AT FOOD CENTRES
(Individual Water Meters)


    11. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for the Environment whether the Public Utilities Board will consider installation of one water meter to each hawker at food centres if the hawkers are prepared to bear the cost of installation.

Column: 345



     Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, a hawker may be given an individual meter if his consumption of water per month is over 20 cubic metres and if he will pay for it. But this practice is not encouraged by the PUB because if every hawker in the market has an individual meter, it means that we would have a maze of pipes running all over the market and all over the stalls.

Column: 345

NEW RESERVOIR IN NEE SOON


    12. Dr Koh Lip Lin asked the Minister for the Environment whether and when a new reservoir will be built in Nee Soon.

     Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, the PUB has plans to build a reservoir in Nee Soon by damming Sungei Seletar sometime in the early 1980s. This reservoir is estimated to have a storage capacity of 11.4 million cubic metres and the cost is estimated at $60 million.

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Sir, would the Minister please inform the House whether there is any survey carried out as to the number of families likely to be affected by the damming?

     Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, before the Ministry carries out its plan, it will have to make a survey of the catchment area and the effect it will have on the population.

Column: 345

LORONG KINCHIR
(Flood alleviation measures)


    13. Dr Lau Teik Soon asked the Minister for the Environment what measures have been taken to alleviate the suffering of the residents in the flood prone areas at the kampong along Lorong Kinchir, off Lorong Chuan.

     Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, the Sungei Kallang is now being widened and deepened to increase the drainage. This project is expected to be completed this year. Meanwhile, the water which flows through this kampong into Sungei Kallang does so through six outlet drains from Ang Mo Kio. When the work of deepening and widening Sungei Kallang is completed this year, the reconstruction of the outlet drains through the

Column: 346

kampong will begin soon. When this is completed next year, the flooding of the kampong at Lorong Kinchir will be alleviated.

    This brings out the point that I was trying to make earlier on to the hon. Member for Kampong Kembangan who asked about the flooding at the junction of Jalan Eunos and the Pan-Island Expressway. Here is a case where it is unwise to spend money on something temporary. It is only after completing the deepening and widening of Sungei Kallang that we should begin to widen and deepen the six canals which drain water from Ang Mo Kio through the Kampong along Lorong Kinchir to Sungei Kallang. This is the sequence to be followed to finalise the drainage for the area.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi: Point of clarification, Sir. I did not make any suggestion about the construction of any temporary canal. I only raised the question whether the Drainage Department has advised the PWD about the implications of the flood relief projects in the area.

     Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, I did not make any mention about the hon. Member making any suggestion to me. What I was saying is that there could have been (I do not know for sure but it is normal) a discussion between the two Ministries. But from what I can gather, it would be better to organise the project by stages in its proper sequence.

Column: 346

WATER METERS
(Checking of)


    14. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for the Environment (a) whether the Public Utilities Board has any plans to systematically check the condition of water meters to detect malfunction and the unnoticed water leakage; (b) how many water meters have been found faulty in the past five years; and (c) how many faulty meters have been replaced with new ones during this period.

     Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, it is the practice of the PUB to recall water meters every five years to check whether they are working properly. Those which are found serviceable

Column: 347

are overhauled and reinstalled for service. Water meters are read bi-monthly and the meter readers also check for faults in the meters. It may come as a surprise to hon. Members to know that faulty meters generally register a lower rate of water consumption. Therefore, it is to the advantage of the PUB to see that the water meters do work properly.

    About 140,000 meters have been found to be faulty and replaced in the past five years. Water leakage results in abnormal increases in meter readings. Such increases are detected by the computer and are investigated by water inspectors.

Column: 347

INCOME TAX RELIEF
(Raising of)


    15. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Finance whether he is aware of the difficulty of the majority of wage-earners to pay their income tax due to the rising cost of living and if he will consider raising the present rate of income tax relief.

     The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, so soon after the Budget session, when the same question of tax relief was asked and debated, the Member for Thomson surely cannot expect any answer than that the present rate of income tax relief will not be increased.

    As far as the first part of his question is concerned, the answer is that I am not aware that there has been much more difficulty in paying income tax recently because of the rising cost of living. The new Consumer Price Index shows that from the base of 100 for the period June 1977 to May 1978, there has been only a 3% rise in prices. The majority of taxpayers have surely had a greater increase than this in their earnings in the comparable period.

    In any case, the cost of living is not a major consideration in deciding our tax relief policy. An objective of taxation policy is to increase our tax base, to spread the load of taxation over as many people as possible, so

Column: 348

THE SINGAPORE ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICE
(Statement by the Minister for Trade and Industry)


     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by the Prime Minister to deliver a Statement on the Singapore Administrative Service on his behalf.

    The quality of a nation depends on the quality of its people and government. Good government requires political and administrative leadership of indisputable integrity, ability and dedication.

    The public sector needs a fair share of the best brains to tackle the complex economic and social problems Singapore will face in the next two decades. The thrust of our economy will continue to depend on the entrepreneurial vigour and business acumen of our private sector but its management will require sophisticated skills and administra-

Column: 359

tive excellence in the public sector. Singapore's rapid development in the last two decades has opened up career opportunities hitherto unavailable for persons with talent outside the public service. The Singapore Administrative Service, as the premier service in the public sector, must therefore be attractive enough for it to recruit and retain a fair proportion of the cream of our graduates. The terms and conditions of the Administrative Service must match the best in the private sector.

    The Government has compared the incomes of graduates in the public and private sectors. This was done by constructing a comprehensive income profile of the graduate population in Singapore from a number of authoritative sources.

    The findings of the income comparison between graduates in the public and private sectors suggest that while the average officer in the Administrative Service earns as much as the average officer in the private sector, the remuneration of the outstanding Administrative Officer is much less than that of the top 5% of the salaried graduates in the private sector. The starting remuneration in the Administrative Service is generally more attractive than in the private sector but the outstanding executive in the private sector soon outstrips his peer in the Administrative Service. Although those who reach the top echelon of the private sector earn far more than the top Administrative Officers, the skills, drive and dedication required of both in the respective sector are comparable. This disparity in rewards puts the highflyers in the Administrative Service at a disadvantage.

    From this study of incomes of graduates in the private sector and the public sector, the Government has concluded that the immediate problem is not one of inadequate financial rewards for the average Administrative Officer. It is the problem of gross disparity between what the outstanding graduates are earning in the private sector

Column: 360

compared to what the highflyers are earning in the Administrative Service. This revision to the salary structure of the Administrative Service is to put right this gap in earnings of top graduates. For the present, a general salary revision is not necessary. Whether a revision will become necessary in 2 - 3 years' time depends on the growth of private sector incomes for the average graduates compared to those in the public sector.

    The outstanding officers in the Administrative Service can best be rewarded through (a) the creation of additional Time-scale, Superscale and Staff Grades, and (b) frequent promotions within the revised salary structure to enable the outstanding officers to maintain parity with their peers in the private sector.

    The Government has, therefore, decided to create the following grades in its Administrative Service: -
